summary: This document is a series of email exchanges from October 2021 between the U.S. Attorney's Office and U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) counsel regarding a Touhy Request and subpoena in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The emails coordinate a meeting to discuss documents previously provided to defense counsel and the circumstances of their disclosure.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Mr. Everdell is the defense counsel who submitted a subpoena request to CBP in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, prompting the email discussion about a Touhy Request.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Maxwell is the defendant in the referenced criminal case (S2 20 Cr. 330) for which the Touhy Request and subpoena are being discussed.

connections.description: Everdell is acting as defense counsel for Maxwell, as evidenced by his submission of a subpoena request on her behalf in her criminal case.

events.title: Scheduled Call on Touhy Request
events.description: A call is scheduled for 9:30 AM between the U.S. Attorney's Office and CBP counsel to discuss a Touhy Request and subpoena related to the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

events.title: Everdell Submits Touhy Request to CBP
events.description: Defense attorney Christian Everdell submits a Touhy request letter to CBP, followed by a subpoena, seeking documents related to the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

locations: One World Trade Center, 50th Floor Suite 50.100, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The communication involves a Touhy Request, which is a process where a federal agency must approve the release of information or testimony from its employees in legal proceedings.
Defense attorney Christian Everdell has subpoenaed U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) for documents in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case.
CBP had previously provided documents to defense counsel, and the meeting is to discuss the circumstances of that disclosure.
The emails are marked as privileged, confidential, and contain attorney work product, indicating sensitive legal discussions.
The correspondence shows coordination between the U.S. Attorney's Office and CBP's Office of the Associate Chief Counsel in New York regarding the Maxwell defense team's document requests.
